did.abstract: Interview conducted by Dale Treleven of the Historical Society staff with Floyd B. Lucia concerning his work in various creameries and as a fieldman for the Wisconsin Cooperative Creamery Association, Baraboo Valley District, from the mid-1920's to 1937, with information on its competition with Land O'Lakes and other creameries, its role in farm social affairs, and related matters.

note.p: Part of the Wisconsin Agriculturalists Oral History Project.

bioghist.p: Floyd B. Lucia was born in Flintville, Wisconsin, on August 6, 1888. Except for brief periods attending the dairy short course at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and serving with the United States Army during World War I, Lucia from 1906 until he retired in the early 1960's worked in the dairy industry. While he was employed in creameries in Illinois and Indiana as well as Wisconsin, Lucia spent over four decades as a fieldman for the Wisconsin Cooperative Creameries Association and as the general manager of the Dried Milk Products Cooperative, Eau Claire, Wisconsin.

scopecontent.p: I [interviewer Dale Treleven] made arrangements to interview Lucia at the urging of Melvin Sprecher, Route 3, Sauk City, Wisconsin, who believed the State Historical Society would be interested in the remembrances of an old creameryman. I taped Lucia in the living room of his apartment on January 15, 1975, while his wife sat nearby, observing the entire interview session. After nearly one and one half hours, it was apparent that Lucia was getting very tired and we decided it would be best for me to return at some mutually agreeable date in the future. Unfortunately, before I had an opportunity to hold another interview session that would have concentrated on his years with the Dried Milk Products Cooperative, Floyd Lucia died on March 17, 1976.

Researchers should welcome Lucia's remembrances of his association with the state's dairy industry, observed by an individual involved in a phase other than dairy farming or retail marketing. He started doing field work at a time when Wisconsin's creameries must give more attention to quality control to compete against private butter plants as well as other cooperatives within and outside the state. Lucia, with quick wit and good humor, relates several anecdotes that help illustrate the relationship between farmers and buttermakers, buttermakers and creamery fieldmen, and fieldmen and private butter buyers. He also reminds us that the cooperative creamery was a social institution as well as an economic organization in the community.

The abstract below lists, in order of discussion, the distinct topics covered on each tape and indicates the time-marking on the user tape at which point the beginning of the particular discussion appears. These time-markings are keyed to a time announcement, heard at five-second intervals, on the second track of each tape.

Thus, the researcher may listen to distinct topics without listening to all of the material on the tapes. For instance, the user who wishes to listen to the topic on Description of Creamery Operation Before 1906 should locate the place on the second track of tape one, side one, where the voice announces the 06:15 time-marking (the voice says at this point, six minutes, fifteen seconds), and at this point switch to the first track to hear the discussion. The discussion on Description of Creamery Operation Before 1906 continues until approximately 10:25 at which point discussion of the next topic (Employment after Short Course Completed) listed in the abstract begins.

Notice that in most cases sentences beneath each headline explain more about the contents of the topic. For example, the sentences underneath Description of Creamery Operation Before 1906 give further details on what appears on the tape between 06:15 and 10:25.
The abstract is designed to provide only a brief outline of the content of the tapes and cannot serve as a substitute for listening to them.

processinfo.p: Finding aid prepared by Dale E. Trevelen, August 30, 1976.

did.unittitle: Introduction
Background and Early Connection with Dairy Industry

scopecontent.p: Born in Flintville where his family worked in lumber. In 1906 began working in uncle's creamery in De Pere. Paid $50.00 per month. After thirteen months took Short Course in dairying at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, which cost $110.00.

did.unittitle: Description of Creamery Operation before 1906

scopecontent.p: Farmers delivered whole milk; took skim milk back for hogs. Farmers talked, smoked or visited tavern while waiting to dump milk or pick up skim.

did.unittitle: Employment after Short Course Completed

scopecontent.p: Various creamery jobs in Iowa and Illinois. Worked at a Kankakee, Illinois creamery, then left for Indiana to make butter for Beatrice Creamery Company.

did.unittitle: Work in Arsenal during World War I

scopecontent.p: Drafted into Army. Because of experience with refrigeration, made gas for shells at arsenal in Maryland.

did.unittitle: Employment after World War I Ends

scopecontent.p: Immediately rehired by Beatrice. Crew dissatisfied with lack of good cream; returned to Wisconsin to take a job with the Lafayette creamery, near Chippewa Falls.

did.unittitle: Anecdote about Soapy Butter at Lafayette Creamery

scopecontent.p: Wife of former buttermaker washed clothes in butter vats. Chicago customers complained of soapy-flavored butter, much to the distress of the creamery's Irish patrons.

did.unittitle: Lucia Becomes Fieldman for Wisconsin Cooperative Creameries Association

scopecontent.p: Became fieldman for District No. Two, Baraboo Valley District, Wisconsin Cooperative Creameries Association in mid-1920's.

did.unittitle: Introduction
Duties as Fieldman for Baraboo Valley District

scopecontent.p: Got acquainted with individual buttermakers, located in thirteen different plants, to help them rather than be regarded as an inspector.

did.unittitle: Contact with Individual Farmers

scopecontent.p: Infrequent contact because cream delivered to creamery by truck. Occasionally accompanied cream truck to talk to individual farmers.

did.unittitle: Buttermakers Urged to Produce at Least 92-Score Butter

scopecontent.p: Buttermakers urged to make the desired 92-score butter. Could recommend dismissal of individual buttermakers if persisted in making poor quality product.

did.unittitle: Testing Milk for Butterfat Content Before and After Development of Babcock Test

scopecontent.p: Explanation of how milk was tested before and after milk tester developed by Professor Babcock at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

did.unittitle: More Discussion on Fieldman's Duties

scopecontent.p: Regular circuit difficult because some creameries needed more attention than others. Most important goal; standardize quality at all factories so butter could be sold in railroad car lots.

did.unittitle: Creameries Begin Direct Sales to Chain Stores

scopecontent.p: Butter originally sold by creameries to commission houses. After districts set up creameries began to market directly to chain stores, especially National Tea and Consumers companies. Lucia met with chain store buyers. Creamery districts did not compete against one another for sales. S. B. Cook, fieldman for District No. Four (Barron County), important in initiating chain store sales in New York as well as Chicago.

did.unittitle: Competition Between Wisconsin Cooperative Creameries and Land 0' Lakes in 1920's

scopecontent.p: Land 0' Lakes in the 1920's tried to break up districts of Wisconsin Cooperative Creameries; succeeded in Polk County.

did.unittitle: Butter Quality Agreement Between Creameries and Chain Stores

scopecontent.p: Gentleman's agreement that creameries produce the best butter possible for chain stores.

did.unittitle: How to Get Proper Moisture Content When Making Butter
Observation on How Some Buttermakers Cut Butterfat Test of Farmers

scopecontent.p: Some buttermakers cut farmer's test to get an overrun.

did.unittitle: End of Part 1 of Tape 1, Side 2

note.p: Tape 1, Side 2 continues with the time-markings beginning again with 00:00.

did.unittitle: Lucia as Fieldman Required to Live in Rural Area

scopecontent.p: Required to live at La Valle, but finally argued successfully that he needed to live at Reedsburg for close access to train.

did.unittitle: Location of Some Creameries in Baraboo Valley District

scopecontent.p: Some located at Cazenovia, La Valle, Elroy. Remembers Gary Carter of Elroy as an important director, and Ed Carlson as good buttermaker.

did.unittitle: End of Part 2 of Tape 1, Side 2
Role of Cooperative Creamery in Community

scopecontent.p: Sponsored many social affairs; entire family attended. Helped develop rapport and openness with patrons and their families, unlike private creameries.

did.unittitle: Effect of Great Depression on Creameries

scopecontent.p: In early-1930's some highbinders down there in the Baraboo Valley participated in milk strikes of 1933. Prevented delivery of milk to creameries, sometimes by threat of force. Recalls that farmers around Hillsboro rather radical.

did.unittitle: Beginning of Lucia's Involvement in Dry Milk Industry

scopecontent.p: Roller dryer improvement meant that small creameries could utilize skim economically and efficiently. Colfax Cooperative Creamery about 1935 one of first in region to install the improved spray dryer.

did.unittitle: Beginning of Lucia's Association with Wisconsin Dried Milk Products Cooperative in Eau Claire

scopecontent.p: Believes a recommendation from Mrs. Lulu Mattson was main reason why he was hired as general manager of the Dried Milk Products Cooperative in 1937.

did.unittitle: End of Interview
